newsitem.title: GERMANY: FRANCE WILL STRUGGLE TO MAKE EMU GRADE - STOIBER.
newsitem.headline: FRANCE WILL STRUGGLE TO MAKE EMU GRADE - STOIBER.

text.p: Bavarian premier Edmund Stoiber was quoted on Friday as saying France would find it difficult to make the grade for Europe's planned single currency.
Stoiber also criticised French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's plans to create 350,000 new jobs in the public sector.

Stoiber, one of the leading advocates of strictly interpreting the membership criteria for monetary union, said he was optimistic Germany would meet the budget deficit target of three percent of gross domestic product (GDP).
"We have good chances of sticking to the three percent. It will be more difficult for the French," he told the Passauer Neue Presse daily in an advance release from Saturday's edition.

"It's counterproductive if Jospin's now taking on 350,000 people in the public service. That doesn't fit in at all with making his country competitive," the paper quoted him as saying. "Inflating the public service is exactly the opposite of what the Americans are doing. They're cutting taxes and even expect a balanced budget without any new debts."
Stoiber is a senior member of the conservative Christian Social Union, the sister party and coalition partners of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats.
